<p>Once the sampler has settled, the samples that come out of MCMC will be drawn from the posterior. However, even in the best of situations, draws which are adjacent are often correlated with each other. The number of "independent" samples, that is, fully independent draws from the posterior can be much fewer than the samples in hand.</p>
<p>emcee has an inbuilt function, <a href="http://dfm.io/emcee/current/api/#emcee.EnsembleSampler.get_autocorr_time"><code>get_autocorr_time()</code></a>, to calculate the auto-correlation length (ACL) (or time) - this is an estimate the number of samples between independent samples in the chain. You can use this number to estimate convergence of chains, and also to thin out chains to produce independent samples. In the example below, the <code>c</code> input parameter for <code>get_autocorr_time()</code> indicates the number of auto-correlation lengths (ACLs) needed to "reliably" calculate the ACL itself. We set it to 1 here because oftentimes, the sampler has not collected enough samples to satsify the default value of 10.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[16]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">m_acl</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c_acl</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sampler</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">get_autocorr_time</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">c</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">quiet</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"The autocorrelation length for m is </span><span class="si">{0}</span><span class="s2"> and c is </span><span class="si">{1}</span><span class="s2">"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">m_acl</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c_acl</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="c1"># thin out the chain</span>
<span class="n">samples_emcee</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sampler</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">chain</span><span class="p">[:,</span> <span class="n">Nburnin</span><span class="p">::</span><span class="nb">int</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">max</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">m_acl</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c_acl</span><span class="p">])),</span> <span class="p">:]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">reshape</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ndims</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Number of independent samples is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2">"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_emcee</span><span class="p">)))</span>

<span class="c1"># plot the resulting posteriors</span>
<span class="n">plotposts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_emcee</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stderr output_text">
<pre>WARNING:root:The chain is shorter than 50 times the integrated autocorrelation time for 1 parameter(s). Use this estimate with caution and run a longer chain!
N/50 = 20;
tau: [13.460736   20.47263475]
</pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>The autocorrelation length for m is 13.460736002049869 and c is 20.472634752316182
Number of independent samples is 2500
</pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
">
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In practice, if you have a minimum number of independent samples that you require then you can repeatedly run the sampler, checking the ACL each time (and maybe adjusting the <code>c</code> input parameter for <code>get_autocorr_time()</code>), until you have collected the required number.</p>
<p>Checking the ACL is something that can be done for any of the samplers discussed in the rest of this notebook. Different sampling methods can lead to different ACLs, and methods that may take more time per sample might end up having shorter ACLs. So, examining the various trade-offs between overall speed and the final number of independent samples can be worthwhile.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="PyMC3">PyMC3<a class="anchor-link" href="#PyMC3"></a></h3><p><a href="http://docs.pymc.io/">PyMC3</a> (<a href="https://peerj.com/articles/cs-55/">Salvatier, Wiecki & Fonnesbeck, 2016</a>) is a Python MCMC implementation that can use a variety of modern sampling method, including "No-U-turn sampling" (NUTS) (<a href="http://www.jmlr.org/papers/v15/hoffman14a.html">Hoffman & Gellman, 2014</a>) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_Monte_Carlo">Hamiltonian Monte Carlo</a> (<a href="http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/037026938791197X">Duane <em>et al</em>, 1987</a>), both of which make use of the gradient of the posterior to efficiently sample the space. An example of getting started using PyMC3 can be found <a href="http://docs.pymc.io/notebooks/getting_started">here</a>, and upon which this example is based.</p>
<p>This code can also be <a href="http://docs.pymc.io/#installation">installed</a> using <code>pip</code> with:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>pip install pymc3
</pre></div>
<p>or with <a href="https://conda.io/docs/index.html">Conda</a> using:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>conda install -c conda-forge pymc3
</pre></div>
<p>and the source is available on GitHub <a href="https://github.com/pymc-devs/pymc3">here</a>.</p>
<p>The majority of distributions that can be used for priors and likelihood functions are <a href="http://docs.pymc.io/api/distributions.html">predefined</a> in PyMC3, so you do not have to worry about writing them yourself (although you can create your <a href="http://docs.pymc.io/notebooks/getting_started.html#Arbitrary-distributions">own custom distribution</a>).</p>
<p>Note that in PyMC3 the prior and likelihood distributions have to be defined within the <a href="http://book.pythontips.com/en/latest/context_managers.html">context</a> of a PyMC3 <a href="https://docs.pymc.io/api/model.html#module-pymc3.model"><code>Model()</code> class</a>, and cannot be defined outside that context (the <code>with</code> statment). Therefore, to set up the model we can't just use the <code>straight_line()</code> function defined above, but can do the following:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[17]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pymc3</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pm</span> <span class="c1"># import PyMC3</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'PyMC3 version: </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pm</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">__version__</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="c1"># set the PyMC3 model</span>
<span class="n">linear_model</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pm</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Model</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="k">with</span> <span class="n">linear_model</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="c1"># set prior parameters</span>
    <span class="n">cmin</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">10.</span> <span class="c1"># lower range of uniform distribution on c</span>
    <span class="n">cmax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span>  <span class="c1"># upper range of uniform distribution on c</span>
    
    <span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.</span>     <span class="c1"># mean of Gaussian distribution on m</span>
    <span class="n">msigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span> <span class="c1"># standard deviation of Gaussian distribution on m</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># set priors for unknown parameters</span>
    <span class="n">cmodel</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pm</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Uniform</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'c'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">lower</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">upper</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cmax</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># uniform prior on y-intercept</span>
    <span class="n">mmodel</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pm</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Normal</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'m'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">mu</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">mmu</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">sd</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">msigma</span><span class="p">)</span>       <span class="c1"># Gaussian prior on gradient</span>
    
    <span class="n">sigmamodel</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sigma</span> <span class="c1"># set a single standard deviation</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># Expected value of outcome, aka "the model"</span>
    <span class="n">mu</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">mmodel</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">cmodel</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># Gaussian likelihood (sampling distribution) of observations, "data"</span>
    <span class="n">Y_obs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pm</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Normal</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Y_obs'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">mu</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">mu</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">sd</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">sigmamodel</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">observed</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>PyMC3 version: 3.6
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now we can perform the sampling. By default, for continuous variables like we have, the <a href="http://docs.pymc.io/api/inference.html#step-methods">sampling step method</a> will use <a href="http://docs.pymc.io/api/inference.html#module-pymc3.step_methods.hmc.nuts">NUTS</a>, but the method can be chosen manually. We'll run with 1000 samples, and tune (like the burn-in discussed <a href="#MCMC-set-up">above</a>) with 1000 samples (discarding these tuning samples):</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[18]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%%</span><span class="k">capture</span>
Nsamples = 1000 # final number of samples
Ntune = 1000    # number of tuning samples

# perform sampling
t0 = time()
with linear_model:
    trace = pm.sample(Nsamples, tune=Ntune, discard_tuned_samples=True); # perform sampling
t1 = time()

timepymc3 = (t1-t0)
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[19]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Time taken to run 'PyMC3' is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2"> seconds"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">timepymc3</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Time taken to run 'PyMC3' is 23.240500926971436 seconds
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>PyMC3 has its own in-built <a href="http://docs.pymc.io/api/plots.html">plotting functions</a> to, for example, show traces of the MCMC chains.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[20]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># plot trace output (overplot the true values)</span>
<span class="n">mpl</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rcParams</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">update</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s1">'font.size'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">12</span><span class="p">})</span> <span class="c1"># make font-size smaller</span>

<span class="n">_</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pm</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">traceplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">trace</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">lines</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'m'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'c'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">})</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
">
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>But, for consistency let's also make a corner plot!</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[21]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">mpl</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rcParams</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">update</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s1">'font.size'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">16</span><span class="p">})</span> <span class="c1"># reset the font size</span>

<span class="n">samples_pymc3</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">vstack</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">trace</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'m'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">trace</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'c'</span><span class="p">]))</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span>

<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mpymc3_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymc3</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mpymc3_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymc3</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cpymc3_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymc3</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cpymc3_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymc3</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ccpymc3'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corrcoef</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymc3</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="c1"># correlation coefficient between parameters</span>

<span class="n">plotposts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymc3</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
">
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Edward">Edward<a class="anchor-link" href="#Edward"></a></h3><p><a href="http://edwardlib.org/">Edward</a> (<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1610.09787">Tran <em>et al</em>, 2016</a>) is a general purpose probabilistic modelling and inference Python library, built on the <a href="https://www.tensorflow.org/">TensorFlow</a> framework. It is not <em>specifically</em> built for performing MCMCs, but can run Hamiltonian MC and Metropolis-Hastings samplers (<a href="http://edwardlib.org/api/inference">among others</a>). It is available on <a href="https://pypi.org/">PyPI</a> and can be installed, along with TensorFlow, with:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>pip install tensorflow edward
</pre></div>
<p>and the source cods is available on GihHub <a href="https://github.com/blei-lab/edward">here</a>.</p>
<blockquote><p>Note: this example will only work with TensorFlow version 1.5 or lower.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Edward's distributions are similar to those for <a href="#PyMC3">PyMC3</a>, but do not have to be defined within a context manager. The priors and likelihood can be set up as follows:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[22]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">edward</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">ed</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">tensorflow</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">tf</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">edward.models</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">Normal</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">Uniform</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">Empirical</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Edward version: </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ed</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">__version__</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'TensorFlow version: </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">__version__</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="c1"># set the priors</span>
<span class="n">cp</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">Uniform</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">low</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">high</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cmax</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">mp</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">Normal</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">mmu</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">scale</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">msigma</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># set the likelihood containing the model</span>
<span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">Normal</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">straight_line</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">mp</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cp</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">scale</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ones</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">)))</span>

<span class="c1"># set parameters to infer</span>
<span class="n">qm</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">Empirical</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Variable</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">zeros</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">Nsamples</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="n">Ntune</span><span class="p">)))</span>
<span class="n">qc</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">Empirical</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Variable</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">zeros</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">Nsamples</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="n">Ntune</span><span class="p">)))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Edward version: 1.3.5
TensorFlow version: 1.5.0
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now we can perform the sampling, and here we will use the Hamiltonian MC method. As for <a href="#PyMC3">PyMC3</a> we will use 1000 tuning samples followed by another 1000 samples. As noting in the <a href="http://www.jmlr.org/papers/v15/hoffman14a.html">NUTS paper</a>), Hamiltonian MCs can be highly sensitive to two tuning parameters, the step size and number of steps. In Edward the step size defaults to 0.25 and the number of steps defaults to 2. In this example we have found that a value of 0.01 for the step size, and 5 steps, gives reasonable results, with larger step sizes leading to zero acceptance rates. However, these two parameters can be very dependent on the particular problem that you have.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[23]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%%</span><span class="k">capture</span>
Nsamples = 1000 # final number of samples
Ntune = 1000    # number of tuning samples

# setup the sampling method
inference = ed.HMC({mp: qm, cp: qc}, data={y: data})

# perform sampling
t0 = time()
inference.run(step_size=1e-2, n_steps=5)  # higher steps sizes can lead to zero acceptance rates
t1 = time()

timeedward = (t1-t0)
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[24]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Time taken to run 'Edward' is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2"> seconds"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">timeedward</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Time taken to run 'Edward' is 2.872471809387207 seconds
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now lets plot the posteriors.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[25]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">mchainedward</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">qm</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">eval</span><span class="p">()[</span><span class="n">Ntune</span><span class="p">:]</span>
<span class="n">cchainedward</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">qc</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">eval</span><span class="p">()[</span><span class="n">Ntune</span><span class="p">:]</span>

<span class="n">samples_edward</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">vstack</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">mchainedward</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cchainedward</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span>

<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'medward_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_edward</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'medward_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_edward</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cedward_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_edward</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cedward_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_edward</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ccedward'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corrcoef</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_edward</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="c1"># correlation coefficient between parameters</span>

<span class="n">plotposts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_edward</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
">
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="TensorFlow-Probability">TensorFlow Probability<a class="anchor-link" href="#TensorFlow-Probability"></a></h3><p><a href="https://www.tensorflow.org/probability/">TensorFlow Probability</a> (TFP) is a probabilistic modelling framework built upon the <a href="https://www.tensorflow.org/">TensorFlow</a> library. It is essentially the successor to <a href="#Edward">Edward</a>, and in fact contains a module called "Edward 2", that provides (among other things) an Edward-like interface to the TFP distribution functions. Like Edward, TFP contains some samplers for performing MCMC. At the time of writing TFP is still fairly new, and <a href="https://github.com/tensorflow/probability/tree/master/tensorflow_probability/python/mcmc">currently includes</a> a Hamiltonian MC sampler, a Metropolis-Hastings sampler, and a slice sampler.</p>
<p>TFP can be <a href="https://github.com/tensorflow/probability#installation">installed</a> from <a href="https://pypi.org/">PyPI</a> via <code>pip</code> with:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>pip install tensorflow-probability
</pre></div>
<p>In this example we won't actually run the TFP sampler  this is because <a href="#Edward">Edward</a> and TFP will only work with incompatible versions of TensorFlow (at the time of writing, the <a href="#Edward">Edward</a> example required TensorFlow version 1.5, whereas TFP requires TensorFlow version 1.10.0) and therefore cannot be installed in the same environment. Instead we will just show the required equivalent code for our linear regression example.</p>
<p>The setup of the model in TFP is similar to that for <a href="#PyMC3">PyMC3</a>, except that it does not require being defined within a context manager. In our example we could set up the probabilistic model with (recalling, if you've not been following from the start of the document(!), that <code>x</code> is our dependent variable at which our straight line model is defined, <code>data</code> is our data containing a straight line and noise, and <code>sigma</code> is the standard deviation of the noise, and <code>straigth_line()</code> is our straight line model function: <code>m*x+c</code>):</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># import edward2 and TensorFlow probability</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">tensorflow_probability</span> <span class="kn">as</span> <span class="nn">tfp</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">tensorflow_probability</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">edward2</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="n">ed</span>  <span class="c1"># edward2 for probability distributions </span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">tensorflow</span> <span class="kn">as</span> <span class="nn">tf</span>

<span class="c1"># define our prior parameters</span>
<span class="n">cmin</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">10.</span>  <span class="c1"># lower range of uniform distribution on c</span>
<span class="n">cmax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span>   <span class="c1"># upper range of uniform distribution on c</span>

<span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of Gaussian distribution on m</span>
<span class="n">msigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span>  <span class="c1"># standard deviation of Gaussian distribution on m</span>

<span class="c1"># define our probabilistic model (priors and likelihood)</span>
<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">log_likelihood</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cmax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">mmu</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">msigma</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">m</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">ed</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Normal</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">mmu</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">scale</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">msigma</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"m"</span><span class="p">)</span>  <span class="c1"># prior on m</span>
    <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">ed</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Uniform</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">low</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">high</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cmax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"c"</span><span class="p">)</span>   <span class="c1"># prior on c</span>

    <span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">ed</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Normal</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">straight_line</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">scale</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"y"</span><span class="p">)</span>  <span class="c1"># likelihood function</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">y</span>
</pre></div>
<p>We now need to convert this model function into a form that TFP can draw samples from. There is a wrapper function in Edward 2, <code>make_log_joint_fn()</code>, that turns our function into one that takes in particular values for all the variables defined in the function (keyed to their given "<code>name</code>" values). We can then also create another new function that just takes in the parameters that we are interested in sampling from. One thing to note, is that if <code>x</code> and <code>data</code> are numpy arrays it is best to convert them to TensorFlow <a href="https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/Tensor">tensor</a> objects before passing them to the functions, and explicity defining their types through the <code>dtype</code> variable (in this case 32-bit floating point numbers).</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># convert function to a "joint" function</span>
<span class="n">log_joint</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">ed</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">make_log_joint_fn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">log_likelihood</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># convert x values and data to tensors</span>
<span class="n">xtensor</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">convert_to_tensor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">float32</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">datatensor</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">convert_to_tensor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">float32</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># function that only takes in the variable parameters</span>
<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">target_log_prob_fn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">"""Target log-probability as a function of states."""</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">log_joint</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">xtensor</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cmax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">mmu</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">msigma</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">m</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">c</span><span class="p">,</span>
                     <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">datatensor</span><span class="p">)</span>  <span class="c1"># define y to be our "observed" data</span>
</pre></div>
<p>We can now set the initial point at which to start the sampler. To do this we'll just draw values of <code>m</code> and <code>c</code> from their prior distributions (note that the <code>dtype</code>s defined here should match our data type).</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># set initial state (drawn from prior)</span>
<span class="n">qm</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random_normal</span><span class="p">([],</span> <span class="n">mean</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">mmu</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">stddev</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">msigma</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">float32</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">qc</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random_uniform</span><span class="p">([],</span> <span class="n">minval</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">maxval</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cmax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">float32</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
<p>We can now set the sampler. In this case we'll use the Hamiltonian MC, and as with <a href="#Edward">Edward</a> we need to set the step size and number of steps, which we again set to 0.01 and 5 respectively. As with many of the above examples we will use 1000 tuning (burn-in) samples and 1000 final posterior samples  TFP will automatically discard the burn-in.</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">Nsamples</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1000</span>  <span class="c1"># final number of samples</span>
<span class="n">Nburn</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1000</span>     <span class="c1"># number of tuning samples</span>

<span class="c1"># set up Hamiltonian MC samler kernel</span>
<span class="n">hmc_kernel</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">tfp</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mcmc</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">HamiltonianMonteCarlo</span><span class="p">(</span>
    <span class="n">target_log_prob_fn</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">target_log_prob_fn</span><span class="p">,</span>  <span class="c1"># the function we're sampling from</span>
    <span class="n">step_size</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.01</span><span class="p">,</span>                         <span class="c1"># the step size</span>
    <span class="n">num_leapfrog_steps</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)</span>                   <span class="c1"># the number of steps (sampler steps not MCMC steps)</span>

<span class="c1"># create the MCMC sampler</span>
<span class="n">states</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">kernel_results</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">tfp</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mcmc</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sample_chain</span><span class="p">(</span>
    <span class="n">num_results</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">Nsamples</span><span class="p">,</span>     <span class="c1"># final number of posterior samples</span>
    <span class="n">current_state</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">qm</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">qc</span><span class="p">],</span>   <span class="c1"># initial state</span>
    <span class="n">kernel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">hmc_kernel</span><span class="p">,</span>        <span class="c1"># sampler step method kernel</span>
    <span class="n">num_burnin_steps</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">Nburn</span><span class="p">)</span>   <span class="c1"># number of burn-in samples</span>
</pre></div>
<p>We cannot yet access the posterior samples as the MCMC has yet to be run. We have to "<a href="https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/Session#run">run</a>" the <code>states</code> within the context of a <a href="https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/Session">TensorFlow session</a>. We can do this as follows:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># run the session to extract the samples</span>
<span class="k">with</span> <span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Session</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="n">sess</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="n">states</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">is_accepted_</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sess</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">run</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">states</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">kernel_results</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">is_accepted</span><span class="p">])</span>  <span class="c1"># run the MCMC</span>
    <span class="n">accepted</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">is_accepted_</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="k">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Acceptance rate: {}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">accepted</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="n">Nsamples</span><span class="p">))</span>  <span class="c1"># print out acceptance rate</span>

<span class="c1"># put posterior chains in a dictionary</span>
<span class="n">results</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">dict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">zip</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s1">'m'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'c'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">states</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="c1"># put posterior chains into a numpy array</span>
<span class="n">postsamples</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">vstack</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">results</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'m'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">results</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'c'</span><span class="p">]))</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span>
</pre></div>
<p>With this array of posterior samples we could plot them in the same way as in any of the other examples.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="PyMC4">PyMC4<a class="anchor-link" href="#PyMC4"></a></h3><p><a href="https://github.com/pymc-devs/pymc4">PyMC4</a> is (at the time of writing) very much in its infancy as a successor to <a href="#PyMC3">PyMC3</a>. It is essentially a wrapper to <a href="#TensorFlow-Probability">TensorFlow Probability</a> and currently has access to the Hamiltonian MC sampler. It can be <a href="https://github.com/pymc-devs/pymc4#installation-instructions">installed</a> from the github page via:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>pip install --user git+https://github.com/pymc-devs/pymc4.git#egg<span class="o">=</span>pymc4
</pre></div>
<p>As it requires TensorFlow Probability (TFP), for the reasons described <a href="#TensorFlow-Probability">above</a> we cannot run it here, but will write out the code that can be used for our linear regression example. This example was aided by the example given <a href="https://sharanry.github.io/post/eight-schools-model/">here</a>.</p>
<p>We first need to initialilise the probabilistic model that we use (as <a href="#TensorFlow-Probability">above</a> we'll convert our data and dependent variable to TensorFlow tensor objects, and explicitly define their types):</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># set up the prior parameters</span>
<span class="n">cmin</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">10.</span>  <span class="c1"># lower range of uniform distribution on c</span>
<span class="n">cmax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span>   <span class="c1"># upper range of uniform distribution on c</span>

<span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of Gaussian distribution on m</span>
<span class="n">msigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span>  <span class="c1"># standard deviation of Gaussian distribution on m</span>

<span class="c1"># convert x values and data to tensors</span>
<span class="n">xtensor</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">convert_to_tensor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">float32</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">datatensor</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">convert_to_tensor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">tf</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">float32</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># PyMC4 specific model initialisation</span>
<span class="n">pymc4_linear_regression</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pm4</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Model</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">datatensor</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">xtensor</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">sigma</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cmin</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cmax</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cmax</span><span class="p">,</span>
                                    <span class="n">mmu</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">msigma</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">10.</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
<p>In the above initialision all the keyword arguments given to the model will be accesible within the model through a <code>cfg</code> variable when we define the model, as shown below:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># create probabilistic model using a "define" decorator</span>
<span class="nd">@pymc4_linear_regression.define</span>
<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">process</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cfg</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">m</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">ed</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Normal</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cfg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mmu</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">scale</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cfg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">msigma</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"m"</span><span class="p">)</span>  <span class="c1"># prior on m</span>
    <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">ed</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Uniform</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">low</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cfg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">high</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">cfg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">cmax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"c"</span><span class="p">)</span>   <span class="c1"># prior on c</span>

    <span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">ed</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Normal</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">straight_line</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">cfg</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">scale</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">float32</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cfg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">name</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"y"</span><span class="p">)</span>  <span class="c1"># likelihood function</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">y</span>
</pre></div>
<p>We now need to set which of the named variables (those defined above with a <code>name</code> argument) within the model are "observed", which in our case is "<code>y</code>" variable given by our data:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># add observed data</span>
<span class="n">pymc4_linear_regression</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">observe</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">datatensor</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
<p>We can now run the MCMC, using the same Hamiltonian MC step size and step number as above, and again with 1000 burn-in samples and 1000 final posterior samples:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">Nsamples</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1000</span>  <span class="c1"># final number of samples</span>
<span class="n">Nburn</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1000</span>     <span class="c1"># number of tuning samples</span>

<span class="c1"># run the sampler</span>
<span class="n">pymc4_trace</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pm4</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sample</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pymc4_linear_regression</span><span class="p">,</span>  <span class="c1"># the model</span>
                         <span class="n">num_results</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">Nsamples</span><span class="p">,</span>     <span class="c1"># final number of posterior samples</span>
                         <span class="n">num_burnin_steps</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">Nburn</span><span class="p">,</span>   <span class="c1"># number of burn-in samples (discarded)</span>
                         <span class="n">step_size</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.01</span><span class="p">,</span>           <span class="c1"># HMC step size</span>
                         <span class="n">num_leapfrog_steps</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)</span>     <span class="c1"># HMC step number</span>

<span class="c1"># convert dictionary of samples to a numpy array</span>
<span class="n">postsamples</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">vstack</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">pymc4_trace</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'m'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">pymc4_trace</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'c'</span><span class="p">]))</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="MCMC-wrapper-samplers">MCMC wrapper samplers<a class="anchor-link" href="#MCMC-wrapper-samplers"></a></h3><p>There are other MCMC samplers that are not pure Python packages, but have a Python-based wrapper to a different library. With these you can't write pure Python model and probability functions, but instead have a create a code string that is then compiled and run using the underlying library functions. We will look at <a href="http://pystan.readthedocs.io">PyStan</a> and <a href="https://pyjags.readthedocs.io">PyJAGS</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="PyStan">PyStan<a class="anchor-link" href="#PyStan"></a></h3><p><a href="http://pystan.readthedocs.io">PyStan</a> is a Python interface to the popular <a href="http://mc-stan.org/">Stan</a> library. As with <a href="#PyMC3">PyMC3</a>, it uses the modern NUTS and Hamiltonain MC sampling methods. It can be <a href="http://pystan.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started.html#installation">installed</a> using <code>pip</code> with:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>pip install pystan
</pre></div>
<p>and the source code is available on GitHub <a href="https://github.com/stan-dev/pystan">here</a>.</p>
<p>To define the model and distributions you need to write a code string like this:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[26]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># model and distributions for straight line fitting</span>
<span class="n">line_code</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"""</span>
<span class="s2">data {{</span>
<span class="s2">    int<lower=0> N;      // number of data points</span>
<span class="s2">    real y[N];           // observed data points</span>
<span class="s2">    real x[N];           // abscissa points</span>
<span class="s2">    real<lower=0> sigma; // standard deviation</span>
<span class="s2">}}</span>
<span class="s2">parameters {{</span>
<span class="s2">    // parameters for the fit</span>
<span class="s2">    real m;</span>
<span class="s2">    real c;</span>
<span class="s2">}}</span>
<span class="s2">transformed parameters {{</span>
<span class="s2">    real theta[N];</span>
<span class="s2">    for (j in 1:N)</span>
<span class="s2">    theta[j] = m * x[j] + c; // straight line model</span>
<span class="s2">}}</span>
<span class="s2">model {{</span>
<span class="s2">    m ~ normal(</span><span class="si">{mmu}</span><span class="s2">, </span><span class="si">{msigma}</span><span class="s2">);     // prior on m (gradient)</span>
<span class="s2">    c ~ uniform(</span><span class="si">{clower}</span><span class="s2">, </span><span class="si">{cupper}</span><span class="s2">); // prior on c (y-intercept)</span>
<span class="s2">    y ~ normal(theta, sigma);        // likelihood of the data given the model</span>
<span class="s2">}}</span>
<span class="s2">"""</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>You can then define the inputs to the <code>data</code> section in a dictionary:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[27]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># set the data and the abscissa</span>
<span class="n">linear_data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'N'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">M</span><span class="p">,</span>          <span class="c1"># number of data points</span>
               <span class="s1">'y'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">,</span>       <span class="c1"># observed data (converted from numpy array to a list)</span>
               <span class="s1">'x'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span>          <span class="c1"># abscissa points (converted from numpy array to a list)</span>
               <span class="s1">'sigma'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">}</span>  <span class="c1"># standard deviation</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now you can compile the model and run the sampler, with 1000 iterations and 4 chains, with:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[28]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%%</span><span class="k">capture</span>
import pystan # import PyStan

Nsamples = 1000 # set the number of iterations of the sampler
chains = 4      # set the number of chains to run with

# dictionary for inputs into line_code
linedict = {}
linedict['mmu'] = 0.0    # mean of Gaussian prior distribution for m
linedict['msigma'] = 10  # standard deviation of Gaussian prior distribution for m
linedict['clower'] = -10 # lower bound on uniform prior distribution for c
linedict['cupper'] = 10  # upper bound on uniform prior distribution for c

t0 = time()
sm = pystan.StanModel(model_code=line_code.format(**linedict)); # compile model
t1 = time()

timepystancomp = (t1-t0)

t0 = time()
fit = sm.sampling(data=linear_data, iter=Nsamples, chains=chains); # perform sampling
t1 = time()

timepystan = (t1-t0)
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[29]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'PyStan version: </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pystan</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">__version__</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Time taken to comile 'PyStan' model is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2"> seconds"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">timepystancomp</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Time taken to run 'PyStan' is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2"> seconds"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">timepystan</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>PyStan version: 2.18.1.0
Time taken to comile 'PyStan' model is 48.467225313186646 seconds
Time taken to run 'PyStan' is 0.3679049015045166 seconds
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>PyStan does have a plotting function (you could run <code>fit.plot()</code>), but we'll extract the chains and use <code>corner.py</code>:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[30]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">la</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">fit</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">extract</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">permuted</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>  <span class="c1"># return a dictionary of arrays</span>

<span class="n">samples_pystan</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">vstack</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">la</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'m'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">la</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'c'</span><span class="p">]))</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span>

<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mpystan_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pystan</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mpystan_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pystan</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cpystan_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pystan</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cpystan_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pystan</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ccpystan'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corrcoef</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pystan</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="c1"># correlation coefficient between parameters</span>

<span class="c1"># plot using corner.py</span>
<span class="n">plotposts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pystan</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
">
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="PyJAGS">PyJAGS<a class="anchor-link" href="#PyJAGS"></a></h3><p><a href="https://pyjags.readthedocs.io">PyJAGS</a> is another wrapper to a non-Python library, in this case the <a href="http://mcmc-jags.sourceforge.net/">JAGS</a> library (<a href="http://www.ci.tuwien.ac.at/Conferences/DSC-2003/Proceedings/Plummer.pdf">Plummer, 2003</a>). As with PyStan, you have to write a code string that is then compiled and run. To use PyJAGS you need to install JAGS, e.g. on a Debian-based system this can be done using:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>sudo apt-get install jags
</pre></div>
<p>and then <a href="https://pyjags.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started.html#installation">install</a> PyJAGS using <code>pip</code> with:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>pip install pyjags
</pre></div>
<p>The source code for PyJAGS is available on GitHub <a href="https://github.com/tmiasko/pyjags">here</a>.</p>
<p>A linear regression fitting example using PyJAGS is given <a href="https://pyjags.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started.html">here</a>, on which this example is based.</p>
<p>We can define the model string using (note that in this model the Gaussian/Normal distribution takes the inverse variance as the second argument, rather than the standard deviation):</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[31]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># create the JAGS code for the linear model</span>
<span class="n">line_code_jags</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'''</span>
<span class="s1">model {{</span>
<span class="s1">    for (i in 1:N) {{</span>
<span class="s1">        y[i] ~ dnorm(c + m * x[i], </span><span class="si">{invvar}</span><span class="s1">) # Gaussian likelihood</span>
<span class="s1">    }}</span>
<span class="s1">    m ~ dnorm(</span><span class="si">{mmu}</span><span class="s1">, </span><span class="si">{minvvar}</span><span class="s1">)     # Gaussian prior on m</span>
<span class="s1">    c ~ dunif(</span><span class="si">{clower}</span><span class="s1">, </span><span class="si">{cupper}</span><span class="s1">)   # Uniform prior on c</span>
<span class="s1">}}</span>
<span class="s1">'''</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>You can then define the data inputs section in a dictionary:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[32]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">datadict</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'x'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span>    <span class="c1"># abscissa points (converted from numpy array to a list)</span>
            <span class="s1">'N'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">M</span><span class="p">,</span>    <span class="c1"># number of data points</span>
            <span class="s1">'y'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">}</span> <span class="c1"># the observed data</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now you can compile the model and run the sampler, with 1000 iterations and 4 chains, with:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[33]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%%</span><span class="k">capture</span>
import pyjags # import PyJAGS

Nsamples = 1000 # set the number of iterations of the sampler
chains = 4      # set the number of chains to run with

# dictionary for inputs into line_code
linedict = {}
linedict['mmu'] = 0.0           # mean of Gaussian prior distribution for m
linedict['minvvar'] = 1/10**2   # inverse variance of Gaussian prior distribution for m
linedict['clower'] = -10        # lower bound on uniform prior distribution for c
linedict['cupper'] = 10         # upper bound on uniform prior distribution for c
linedict['invvar'] = 1/sigma**2 # inverse variance of the data

# compile model
t0 = time()
model = pyjags.Model(line_code_jags.format(**linedict), data=datadict, chains=chains)
t1 = time()

timepyjagscomp = (t1-t0)

t0 = time()
samples = model.sample(Nsamples, vars=['m', 'c']) # perform sampling
t1 = time()

timepyjags = (t1-t0)
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[34]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'PyJAGS version: </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pyjags</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">__version__</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Time taken to comile 'PyJAGS' model is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2"> seconds"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">timepyjagscomp</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Time taken to run 'PyJAGS' is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2"> seconds"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">timepyjags</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>PyJAGS version: 1.2.2
Time taken to comile 'PyJAGS' model is 0.37364649772644043 seconds
Time taken to run 'PyJAGS' is 0.16295576095581055 seconds
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now we can plot the samples using <code>corner.py</code>:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[35]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">mchainjags</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">samples</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'m'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">flatten</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">cchainjags</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">samples</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'c'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">flatten</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="n">samples_pyjags</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">vstack</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">mchainjags</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cchainjags</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span>

<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mpyjags_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pyjags</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mpyjags_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pyjags</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cpyjags_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pyjags</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cpyjags_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pyjags</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ccpyjags'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corrcoef</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pyjags</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="c1"># correlation coefficient between parameters</span>

<span class="c1"># plot using corner.py</span>
<span class="n">plotposts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pyjags</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
">
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>That ends our exploration of MCMC codes. We now move on to Nested Sampling!</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Nested-Sampling">Nested Sampling<a class="anchor-link" href="#Nested-Sampling"></a></h2><p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nested_sampling_algorithm">Nested sampling</a> (<a href="https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.ba/1340370944">Skilling, 2006</a>) is a method to numerically perform the integral required to evaluate the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marginal_likelihood">marginal likelihood</a> of the data given a particular model. This is not a value that is produced by most standard MCMC methods, but is a value that is very useful if wanting to do <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayes_factor">Bayesian model comparison</a>. Above, we defined the marginal likelihood, or <em>evidence</em>, as</p>
$$
p(\mathbf{d}|I) = \int^{\forall \theta_i \in \vec{\theta}} p(\mathbf{d}|\vec{\theta},I) p(\vec{\theta}|I) {\rm d}{\theta_i},
$$<p>but, we can make this more explicit for a given hypothesis, or model, $H_j$, by stating:</p>
$$
p(\mathbf{d}|H_j, I) \equiv Z = \int^{\forall \theta_i \in \vec{\theta}} p(\mathbf{d}|\vec{\theta}, H_j, I) p(\vec{\theta}|H_j,I) {\rm d}{\theta_i},
