$$<p>where previously the $H_j$ had been subsumed inside our implicit assumptions, $I$.</p>
<p>Nested sampling algorithms generally start by drawing a set of points (sometimes called <em>"live points"</em>, or <em>"active points"</em>) from the prior distribution. It relies on these points truely being independent draws from the prior, otherwise the resulting marginal likelihood value can be biased. The likelihood is evaluated at each point, and the smallest likelihood point is found. This points is then removed from the set of live points (and goes into the sum calculating the marginal likelihood integral) and a new point is drawn from the prior with the constraint that it has a likelihood larger than the just removed point. Drawing truely independent points from this constrained prior is the main tricky part of nested sampling (particularly when the number of parameters is not small), and a variety of methods (including MCMC methods) can be used.</p>
<p>The uncertainty on the estimate of the natural logarithm marginal likelihood, $\ln{Z}$, can be found if the information gain (or <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kullback%E2%80%93Leibler_divergence">Kullback-Leibler divergence</a>), $h$, in going from the prior to the posterior is calculated. If $h$ (in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nat_%28unit%29">nats</a>) is available then the uncertainty is (<a href="https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.ba/1340370944">Skilling, 2006</a>):</p>
$$
\sqrt{\frac{h}{N_{\rm live}}},
$$<p>where $N_{\rm live}$ is the number of live points used.</p>
<blockquote><p><em>Note</em>: <em>This is the statistical uncertainty on the value, but if there are any biases due to the sampling not being independent draws from the prior then there can be systematic uncertainties too.</em></p>
</blockquote>
<p>As well as producing a value for the marginal likelihood, a by-product of the nested sampling algorithm to to produce a set of samples that can be re-sampled from to produce samples drawn from the posterior distribution.</p>
<blockquote><p><em>Note</em>: <em>MCMC methods can be used to estimate the marginal likelihood, e.g. <code>emcee</code> can be run with a <a href="http://dfm.io/emcee/current/user/pt/">parallel tempering sampling method</a> and used to compute the evidence using thermodynamic integration (e.g., <a href="http://aip.scitation.org/doi/abs/10.1063/1.1751356">Goggans & Chi, 2004</a>), or potentially using Slice sampling with PyMC3.</em></p>
</blockquote>
<p>As with MCMC, there are various codes available to perform the nested sampling algorithm. We will again look at pure Python implementations and some that are wrappers to other libraries.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Nestle">Nestle<a class="anchor-link" href="#Nestle"></a></h3><p><a href="http://kylebarbary.com/nestle/">Nestle</a> is a pure Python nested sampling algorithm. It has three options for the method with which it draws new samples: <a href="http://kylebarbary.com/nestle/#mcmc-exploration-method-classic">"classic"</a>, <a href="http://kylebarbary.com/nestle/#single-ellipsoid-method-single">"single ellipsoid"</a>, and <a href="http://kylebarbary.com/nestle/#multiple-ellipsoids-method-multi">"multiple ellipsoids</a>. In this example we'll make use of the last of these. This uses the MultiNest method (also see <a href="#PyMultiNest">PyMultiNest below</a>) (<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/0809.3437">Feroz <em>et al</em>, 2009</a>) in which the current live points are clustered (however, clustering is not re-done at every iteration of the algorithm), ellipsoids completely bounding each cluster are found, an ellipsoid is randomly chosen with a probability proportional to its volume, and a new sample is drawn uniformly from it.</p>
<p>Nestle is available on PyPI and installable using <code>pip</code> with:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>pip install nestle
</pre></div>
<p>The source code is available on GitHub <a href="https://github.com/kbarbary/nestle">here</a>.</p>
<p>The set up of likelihood functions is quite similar to that for <a href="#emcee">emcee</a>, but the prior that is used is a unit hypercube (an $n$-dimensional cube with all sides equal to one), so parameters must be mapped into this space. This is simple for uniform priors, but requires a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probability_density_function#Dependent_variables_and_change_of_variables">re-parameterisation</a> using a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacobian_matrix_and_determinant">Jacobian</a> for more complex priors (if possible).</p>
<p>For our Gaussian prior on $m$ we can't analytically re-parameterise it for a unit hypercube, however we can use <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_transform_sampling">inverse transform sampling</a> to take samples from a uniform range between 0 and 1, and convert them back to a Gaussian, e.g.</p>
$$
m = \mu_m + \sqrt{2}\sigma_m {\rm erf}^{-1}\left(2c - 1\right),
$$<p>where $c \sim {\rm Uniform}(0,1)$ and ${\rm erf}^{-1}$ is the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Error_function#Inverse_functions">inverse error function</a>. As <a href="http://kylebarbary.com/nestle/prior.html#non-uniform-priors">shown in the Nestle documentation</a> we can use the <a href="https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.special.ndtri.html#scipy.special.ndtri"><code>scipy.special.ndtri</code></a> function for this.</p>
<p>An example of using Nestle for the linear regression problem, but with uniform priors on both parameters, is given <a href="http://kylebarbary.com/nestle/examples/plot_line.html#sphx-glr-examples-plot-line-py">here</a>.</p>
<h4 id="Setting-the-prior-transform">Setting the prior transform<a class="anchor-link" href="#Setting-the-prior-transform"></a></h4><p>Given the above description, rather than setting a prior function, we set a <a href="http://kylebarbary.com/nestle/prior.html">prior transformation function</a> that maps from parameters drawn from the unit hypercube into the true parameters.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[36]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># import the inverse error function from scipy</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">scipy.special</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">ndtri</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">prior_transform</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">theta</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">    A function defining the tranform between the parameterisation in the unit hypercube</span>
<span class="sd">    to the true parameters.</span>

<span class="sd">    Args:</span>
<span class="sd">        theta (tuple): a tuple containing the parameters.</span>
<span class="sd">        </span>
<span class="sd">    Returns:</span>
<span class="sd">        tuple: a new tuple or array with the transformed parameters.</span>
<span class="sd">    """</span>

    <span class="n">mprime</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cprime</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">theta</span> <span class="c1"># unpack the parameters (in their unit hypercube form)</span>

    <span class="n">cmin</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">10.</span>  <span class="c1"># lower bound on uniform prior on c</span>
    <span class="n">cmax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span>   <span class="c1"># upper bound on uniform prior on c</span>

    <span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.</span>     <span class="c1"># mean of Gaussian prior on m</span>
    <span class="n">msigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span> <span class="c1"># standard deviation of Gaussian prior on m</span>

    <span class="n">m</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">msigma</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">ndtri</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mprime</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># convert back to m</span>
    <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">cprime</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cmax</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">cmin</span>  <span class="c1"># convert back to c</span>

    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Setting-the-likelihood-function">Setting the likelihood function<a class="anchor-link" href="#Setting-the-likelihood-function"></a></h4><p>This is similar to setting the likelihood function for <a href="#Likelihood">emcee</a> except, as we're calculating the marginal likelihood, we will keep the normalisation constants. As before, we work with the natural logarithm of the likelihood function. The function can only take in a tuple variable containing the parameter values, so any additional required values must be hard coded, or set as global variables.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[37]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># set the natural logarithm of 2pi, so that it doesn't have to be recalculated</span>
<span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">2.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pi</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">LNSIGMA</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># natural log of the data noise standard deviation</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">loglikelihood_nestle</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">theta</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">    The log-likelihood function.</span>
<span class="sd">    """</span>

    <span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">theta</span> <span class="c1"># unpack the parameters</span>

    <span class="c1"># normalisation</span>
    <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">M</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">M</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">LNSIGMA</span>

    <span class="c1"># chi-squared (data, sigma and x are global variables defined early on in this notebook)</span>
    <span class="n">chisq</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(((</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">straight_line</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>

    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">chisq</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now you can run the sampler. We'll use 1024 live/active points (there's nothing special about this number, and powers of two are not required). The more live points you use the longer the code will take to run, but the uncertainty on the final marginal likelihood value will decrease with greater numbers of live points.</p>
<p>Unlike with MCMCs, where you give it a number of iterations to run and after that point it stops, nested sampling needs to be supplied with a <a href="http://kylebarbary.com/nestle/stopping.html">stopping criterion</a> at which point it will terminate. One common <a href="http://kylebarbary.com/nestle/stopping.html#estimated-remaining-evidence">criterion</a> is based on the ratio between an estimate of the total evidence and the current calculated evidence value. Once this value gets below some set value the algorithm will terminate.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[38]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># import nestle</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">nestle</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Nestle version: </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">nestle</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">__version__</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="n">nlive</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1024</span>     <span class="c1"># number of live points</span>
<span class="n">method</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'multi'</span> <span class="c1"># use MutliNest algorithm</span>
<span class="n">ndims</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">2</span>        <span class="c1"># two parameters</span>
<span class="n">tol</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.1</span>        <span class="c1"># the stopping criterion</span>

<span class="n">t0</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">time</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">res</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">nestle</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sample</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loglikelihood_nestle</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">prior_transform</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ndims</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">method</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">method</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">npoints</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">nlive</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dlogz</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">tol</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">t1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">time</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="n">timenestle</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">t1</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">t0</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Time taken to run 'Nestle' is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2"> seconds"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">timenestle</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Nestle version: 0.2.0
Time taken to run 'Nestle' is 1.7340619564056396 seconds
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can extract the value of the marginal likelihood, $\ln{Z}$, and its uncertainties with the following:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[39]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">logZnestle</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">res</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">logz</span>                         <span class="c1"># value of logZ</span>
<span class="n">infogainnestle</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">res</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">h</span>                        <span class="c1"># value of the information gain in nats</span>
<span class="n">logZerrnestle</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sqrt</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">infogainnestle</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">nlive</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># estimate of the statistcal uncertainty on logZ</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">six</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">u</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'log(Z) = </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="se">\u00B1</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">logZnestle</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">logZerrnestle</span><span class="p">)))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>log(Z) = -87.71393823175327  0.1007809964134658
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>A summary of the above values can also be output using:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[40]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">res</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">summary</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>niter: 14078
ncall: 23377
nsamples: 15102
logz: -87.714 +/-  0.101
h: 10.401
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>As mentioned above, the samples output by nested sampling are not drawn from the posterior, and as such need to be resampled from using certain weights. These weights are output by Nestle in the results. We can get posterior samples with the following:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[41]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># re-scale weights to have a maximum of one</span>
<span class="n">nweights</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">res</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">weights</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">max</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">res</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">weights</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># get the probability of keeping a sample from the weights</span>
<span class="n">keepidx</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">where</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rand</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">nweights</span><span class="p">))</span> <span class="o"><</span> <span class="n">nweights</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="c1"># get the posterior samples</span>
<span class="n">samples_nestle</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">res</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">samples</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">keepidx</span><span class="p">,:]</span>

<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mnestle_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_nestle</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mnestle_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_nestle</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cnestle_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_nestle</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cnestle_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_nestle</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ccnestle'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corrcoef</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_nestle</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="c1"># correlation coefficient between parameters</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'nestle_npos'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_nestle</span><span class="p">)</span>              <span class="c1"># number of posterior samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'nestle_time'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">timenestle</span>                       <span class="c1"># run time</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'nestle_logZ'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">logZnestle</span>                       <span class="c1"># log marginalised likelihood</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'nestle_logZerr'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">logZerrnestle</span>                 <span class="c1"># uncertainty on log(Z)</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Number of posterior samples is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_nestle</span><span class="p">)))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Number of posterior samples is 2782
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now we can plot the posteriors:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[42]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">plotposts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_nestle</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
">
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="CPNest">CPNest<a class="anchor-link" href="#CPNest"></a></h3><p><a href="https://johnveitch.github.io/cpnest/">CPNest</a> (<a href="http://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.835874">Veitch & del Pozzo, 2017</a>) is another pure Python nested sampling algorithm. To perform the sampling from the restricted prior it uses a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolis%E2%80%93Hastings_algorithm">Metropolis-Hastings</a> based MCMC, with sample proposal distributions that use a combination of the affine invarient ensemble methods described for <a href="#emcee">emcee</a> (<a href="https://msp.org/camcos/2010/5-1/p04.xhtml">Goodman & Weare, 2010</a>), <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_evolution">differential evolution</a>, or jumps based on the eigenvectors of the covariance matrix of live points.</p>
<p>CPNest is available on PyPI and can be installed using <code>pip</code> with:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>pip install cpnest
</pre></div>
<p>The source code is available on GitHub <a href="https://github.com/johnveitch/cpnest/">here</a>.</p>
<p>To run CPNest we have to define a <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/classes.html">class</a> containing the likelihood and prior functions. CPNest also requires explicit bounds on all parameters from which it will uniformly draw an initial set of live points. Prior to running the nested sampling algorithm, it will run an MCMC using the prior as the target distribution to make sure the samples are drawn from the required prior.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[43]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># import the Model class from CPNest</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">cpnest.model</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">Model</span>

<span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">2.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pi</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># set the model, likelihood and prior</span>
<span class="k">class</span> <span class="nc">StraightLineModel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">Model</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">    A simple straight line model, with a Gaussian likelihood.</span>
<span class="sd">    </span>
<span class="sd">    Args:</span>
<span class="sd">        data (:class:`numpy.ndarray`): an array containing the observed data</span>
<span class="sd">        abscissa (:class:`numpy.ndarray`): an array containing the points at which the data were taken</span>
<span class="sd">        modelfunc (function): a function defining the model</span>
<span class="sd">        sigma (float): the standard deviation of the noise in the data</span>
<span class="sd">        </span>
<span class="sd">    """</span>
    <span class="n">names</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'m'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'c'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="c1"># parameter names (this is a required variables for the class)</span>

    <span class="c1"># define the boundaries using for initial sampling of the live points</span>
    <span class="n">cmin</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">10.</span>  <span class="c1"># lower range on c (the same as the uniform c prior lower bound)</span>
    <span class="n">cmax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span>   <span class="c1"># upper range on c (the same as the uniform c prior upper bound)</span>

    <span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.</span>     <span class="c1"># mean of the Gaussian prior on m</span>
    <span class="n">msigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span> <span class="c1"># standard deviation of the Gaussian prior on m</span>

    <span class="n">cbounds</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cmax</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="c1"># set the m bounds to be +/- 10sigma about the mean</span>
    <span class="n">mbounds</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">mmu</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">10.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">msigma</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">mmu</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="mf">10.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">msigma</span><span class="p">]</span>

    <span class="c1"># NOTE: the bounds could instead be set through arguments passed to the __init__</span>
    <span class="c1"># function for the class if wanted</span>
    <span class="n">bounds</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">mbounds</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cbounds</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="c1"># upper and lower bounds on each parameter (required for the class)</span>

    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">__init__</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">abscissa</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">modelfunc</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="c1"># set the data</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span>         <span class="c1"># oberserved data</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_abscissa</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">abscissa</span> <span class="c1"># points at which the observed data are taken</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_sigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sigma</span>       <span class="c1"># standard deviation(s) of the data</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_logsigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># log sigma here to save computations in the likelihood</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_ndata</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">)</span>   <span class="c1"># number of data points</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_model</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">modelfunc</span>   <span class="c1"># model function</span>

    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">log_likelihood</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">        The natural logarithm of the likelihood function.</span>

<span class="sd">        Args:</span>
<span class="sd">            params (dict): a dictionary keyed to the parameter names.</span>

<span class="sd">        Returns:</span>
<span class="sd">            float: the log likelihood value.</span>
<span class="sd">        """</span>
        <span class="c1"># extract the parameters</span>
        <span class="n">m</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'m'</span><span class="p">]</span>
        <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'c'</span><span class="p">]</span>

        <span class="c1"># calculate the model</span>
        <span class="n">model</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_model</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">)</span>

        <span class="c1"># normalisation</span>
        <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_ndata</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_ndata</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_logsigma</span>

        <span class="c1"># chi-squared</span>
        <span class="n">chisq</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(((</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_data</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">model</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_sigma</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>

        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">chisq</span>

    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">log_prior</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">p</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">        The natural logarithm of the prior function.</span>

<span class="sd">        Args:</span>
<span class="sd">            p (dict): a dictionary keyed to parameter names.</span>

<span class="sd">        Returns:</span>
<span class="sd">            float: The log prior value.</span>
<span class="sd">        """</span>
        <span class="c1"># the uniform priors are dealt with by just checking that we're within the bounds</span>
        <span class="k">if</span> <span class="ow">not</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">in_bounds</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">p</span><span class="p">):</span> <span class="k">return</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">inf</span> <span class="c1"># check parameters are all in bounds</span>

        <span class="c1"># Gaussian prior on m</span>
        <span class="n">lp</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.</span>
        <span class="n">m</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">p</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'m'</span><span class="p">]</span>
        <span class="n">lp</span> <span class="o">-=</span> <span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">m</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mmu</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">msigma</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="c1"># no need for normalisation constant on the prior</span>

        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">lp</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can now run CPNest. As with Nestle we will use 1024 live points. CPNest can use mutltiple CPU cores, but we'll set it to use one to be comparable to the other tests. The number of iterations used for the MCMC sampling is automatically worked out within the code by calculating autocorrelation lengths to see how many iterations are needed to produce independent samples, but a maximum chain length can also be set. We'll set this to 1024. As with Nestle a stopping criterion is required, which for CPNest is defined in the same way as Nestle. The current CPNest default is 0.1 and this cannot be altered by the user.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[44]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%%</span><span class="k">capture</span>
# import cpnest
import cpnest

print('CPNest version: {}'.format(cpnest.__version__))

nlive = 1024      # number of live point
maxmcmc = 1024    # maximum MCMC chain length
nthreads = 1      # use one CPU core

# set up the algorithm
work = cpnest.CPNest(StraightLineModel(data, x, straight_line, sigma), verbose=0,
                     nthreads=nthreads, nlive=nlive, maxmcmc=maxmcmc);
# run the algorithm
t0 = time()
work.run();
t1 = time()

timecpnest = (t1-t0)
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[45]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Time taken to run 'CPNest' is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2"> seconds"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">timecpnest</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Time taken to run 'CPNest' is 20.286734104156494 seconds
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can again extract the value of $\ln{Z}$ and its uncertainty. One simple bit of model comparison that we may want to do is compare the evidence for the model of the data containg a straight line (with the given priors on the parameter), with the evidence for a model that the data just contains independent Gaussian noise with the given standard deviation. We can calculate the latter evidence easily by just setting the model to zero in the log-likelihood function, e.g.:</p>
$$
\ln{Z}_{\rm noise} = -\frac{M}{2}\ln{(2\pi)} - \ln\left(\prod_{i=1}^M \sigma_i\right) - \sum_{i=1}^M\frac{d_i^2}{2\sigma_i^2}.
$$<p>The natural logarithm of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayes_factor">Bayes factor</a> comparing the two models is then:</p>
$$
\ln{\mathcal{B}} = \ln{Z} - \ln{Z}_{\rm noise}.
$$<p>We will also extract this value.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[46]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">logZcpnest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">work</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">NS</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">logZ</span>                     <span class="c1"># value of log Z</span>
<span class="n">infogaincpnest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">work</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">NS</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">state</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">info</span>           <span class="c1"># value of the information gain</span>
<span class="n">logZerrcpnest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sqrt</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">infogaincpnest</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">nlive</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># estimate of the statistcal uncertainty on logZ</span>

<span class="c1"># get the null log likelihood (evidence that the data is Gaussian noise with zero mean, and given standard devaition)</span>
<span class="n">logZnull</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">work</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">user</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log_likelihood</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s1">'m'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mf">0.</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'c'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mf">0.</span><span class="p">})</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">six</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">u</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'log(Z) = </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="se">\u00B1</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">logZcpnest</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">logZerrcpnest</span><span class="p">)))</span>

<span class="c1"># output the log Bayes factor</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'log Bayes factor is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">logZcpnest</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">logZnull</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>log(Z) = -87.87308214393768  0.10147700889151604
log Bayes factor is 89069.58807590591
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>CPNest will itself resample from the nested samples to give posterior samples held in a dictionary, which we can plot.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[47]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">mchain_cpnest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">work</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">posterior_samples</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'m'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="c1"># extract chain of m values</span>
<span class="n">cchain_cpnest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">work</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">posterior_samples</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'c'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="c1"># extract chain if c values</span>
<span class="n">samples_cpnest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">vstack</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">mchain_cpnest</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cchain_cpnest</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span>

<span class="c1"># print out the number of posterior samples</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Number of posterior samples is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_cpnest</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]))</span>

<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mcpnest_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_cpnest</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mcpnest_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_cpnest</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ccpnest_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_cpnest</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ccpnest_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_cpnest</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cccpnest'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corrcoef</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_cpnest</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="c1"># correlation coefficient between parameters</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cpnest_npos'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_cpnest</span><span class="p">)</span>              <span class="c1"># number of posterior samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cpnest_time'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">timecpnest</span>                       <span class="c1"># run time</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cpnest_logZ'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">logZcpnest</span>                       <span class="c1"># log marginalised likelihood</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cpnest_logZerr'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">logZerrcpnest</span>                 <span class="c1"># uncertainty on log(Z)</span>

<span class="c1"># plot using corner.py</span>
<span class="n">plotposts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_cpnest</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Number of posterior samples is 2764
</pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
">
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="dynesty">dynesty<a class="anchor-link" href="#dynesty"></a></h3><p><a href="https://dynesty.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html">dynesty</a> is a pure Python-based implementation of the dynamic nested sampling algorithm (<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1704.03459">Higson <em>et al</em>, 2017</a>). It is very similar in usage to <a href="#Nestle">Nestle</a>. Dynamic nested sampling is a way of dynamically adapting the number of live points used to provide more accurate evidence estimates and/or larger numbers of independent posterior samples. The code can run using dynamic adjustment or live points or just in a "static" mode with a fixed number of live points. There a many options for how the new live points are drawn, both in terms of the <a href="https://dynesty.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#module-dynesty.bounding">bounds</a> from which they are drawn and the <a href="https://dynesty.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#module-dynesty.sampling">sampling</a> from within those bounds. The bound options include the using bounding ellipsoids in the style of <a href="#PyMultiNest">MultiNest</a>, or the RadFriends algorithm of <a href="#UltraNest">UltraNest</a>, among others. The sampling options include uniform draws from the bounds, random walks, or slice sampling in the style of <a href="#PyPolyChord">PolyChord</a>.</p>
<p>dynesty is available on <a href="https://pypi.org/">PyPI</a> and can be installed with <code>pip</code> using:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>pip install dynesty
</pre></div>
<blockquote><p><em>Note</em>: <em>Other dynamic nested sampling codes exist such as <a href="http://dypolychord.readthedocs.io/en/latest/">dyPolyChord</a> and</em> <a href="https://github.com/ejhigson/perfectns"><code>perfectns</code></a>.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>The likelihood function and prior transform can be set up in a way that is identical to <a href="#Nestle">Nestle</a> (we'll define both again below for completeness), with the differences being in how the sampler is called. Here we will show the sampling being used for both "<em>static</em>" and "<em>dynamic</em>" nested sampling.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[48]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># import the inverse error function from scipy</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">scipy.special</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">ndtri</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">prior_transform</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">theta</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">    A function defining the tranform between the parameterisation in the unit hypercube</span>
<span class="sd">    to the true parameters.</span>

<span class="sd">    Args:</span>
<span class="sd">        theta (tuple): a tuple containing the parameters.</span>
<span class="sd">        </span>
<span class="sd">    Returns:</span>
<span class="sd">        tuple: a new tuple or array with the transformed parameters.</span>
<span class="sd">    """</span>

    <span class="n">mprime</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cprime</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">theta</span> <span class="c1"># unpack the parameters (in their unit hypercube form)</span>

    <span class="n">cmin</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">10.</span>  <span class="c1"># lower bound on uniform prior on c</span>
    <span class="n">cmax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span>   <span class="c1"># upper bound on uniform prior on c</span>

    <span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.</span>     <span class="c1"># mean of Gaussian prior on m</span>
    <span class="n">msigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span> <span class="c1"># standard deviation of Gaussian prior on m</span>

    <span class="n">m</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">msigma</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">ndtri</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mprime</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># convert back to m</span>
    <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">cprime</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cmax</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">cmin</span>  <span class="c1"># convert back to c</span>

    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">)</span>


<span class="c1"># set the natural logarithm of 2pi, so that it doesn't have to be recalculated</span>
<span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">2.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pi</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">LNSIGMA</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># natural log of the data noise standard deviation</span>


<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">loglikelihood_dynesty</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">theta</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">    The log-likelihood function.</span>
<span class="sd">    """</span>

    <span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">theta</span> <span class="c1"># unpack the parameters</span>

    <span class="c1"># normalisation</span>
    <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">M</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">M</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">LNSIGMA</span>

    <span class="c1"># chi-squared (data, sigma and x are global variables defined early on in this notebook)</span>
    <span class="n">chisq</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(((</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">straight_line</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>

    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">chisq</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>First we'll run with the "static" sampler. For consistency with <a href="#Nestle">Nestle</a> and <a href="#CPNest">CPNest</a> we'll use 1024 live points and a stopping criterion of 0.1. As with our <a href="#Example">Nestle</a> we will use the <a href="#PyMultiNest">MultiNest</a>-style bounding ellipsoids, but with <a href="https://dynesty.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#dynesty.sampling.sample_rwalk">random walk</a> sampling.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[49]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># import dynesty</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">dynesty</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'dynesty version: </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">dynesty</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">__version__</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="n">nlive</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1024</span>      <span class="c1"># number of live points</span>
<span class="n">bound</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'multi'</span>   <span class="c1"># use MutliNest algorithm for bounds</span>
<span class="n">ndims</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">2</span>         <span class="c1"># two parameters</span>
<span class="n">sample</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'rwalk'</span>  <span class="c1"># random walk sampling</span>
<span class="n">tol</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.1</span>         <span class="c1"># the stopping criterion</span>

<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">dynesty</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">NestedSampler</span>

<span class="n">sampler</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">NestedSampler</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loglikelihood_dynesty</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">prior_transform</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ndims</span><span class="p">,</span>
                        <span class="n">bound</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">bound</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">sample</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">sample</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">nlive</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">nlive</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">t0</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">time</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">sampler</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">run_nested</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">dlogz</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">tol</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">print_progress</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># don't output progress bar</span>
<span class="n">t1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">time</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="n">timedynesty</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">t1</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">t0</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Time taken to run 'dynesty' (in static mode) is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2"> seconds"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">timedynesty</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>dynesty version: 0.9.2
Time taken to run 'dynesty' (in static mode) is 20.429600715637207 seconds
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can extract the value of the marginal likelihood, $\ln{Z}$, and its uncertainties with the following:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[50]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">res</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sampler</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">results</span> <span class="c1"># get results dictionary from sampler</span>

<span class="n">logZdynesty</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">res</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">logz</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>        <span class="c1"># value of logZ</span>
<span class="n">logZerrdynesty</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">res</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">logzerr</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="c1"># estimate of the statistcal uncertainty on logZ</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">six</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">u</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'log(Z) = </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="se">\u00B1</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">logZdynesty</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">logZerrdynesty</span><span class="p">)))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>log(Z) = -87.91559939888346  0.10167637802636009
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Or, get a summary of this information using:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[51]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">res</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">summary</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Summary
=======
nlive: 1024
niter: 14290
ncall: 300159
eff(%):  5.102
logz: -87.916 +/-  0.102
None
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>As with <a href="#Nestle">Nestle</a> we need to draw posterior samples from the nested samples based on their prior weights.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[52]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># get function that resamples from the nested samples to give sampler with equal weight</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">dynesty.utils</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">resample_equal</span>

<span class="c1"># draw posterior samples</span>
<span class="n">weights</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">exp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">res</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'logwt'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">res</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'logz'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">samples_dynesty</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">resample_equal</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">res</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">samples</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">weights</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mdynesty_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dynesty</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mdynesty_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dynesty</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cdynesty_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dynesty</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cdynesty_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dynesty</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ccdynesty'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corrcoef</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dynesty</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="c1"># correlation coefficient between parameters</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'dynesty_npos'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dynesty</span><span class="p">)</span>              <span class="c1"># number of posterior samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'dynesty_time'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">timedynesty</span>                       <span class="c1"># run time</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'dynesty_logZ'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">logZdynesty</span>                       <span class="c1"># log marginalised likelihood</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'dynesty_logZerr'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">logZerrdynesty</span>                 <span class="c1"># uncertainty on log(Z)</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Number of posterior samples is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dynesty</span><span class="p">)))</span>

<span class="c1"># plot using corner.py</span>
<span class="n">plotposts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dynesty</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Number of posterior samples is 15314
</pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
">
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can now do the same thing, but with the "dynamic" sampler. For this we can specify an initial number of live points (we will stick with 1024), but the actual number used will evolve. The <a href="https://dynesty.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dynamic.html#stopping-function">stopping criterion</a> for the dynamic method is more complex than for the static case, and we will just leave it at the default values.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[53]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># import the dynamic nested sampler</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">dynesty</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">DynamicNestedSampler</span>

<span class="c1"># set up the sampler</span>
<span class="n">dsampler</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">DynamicNestedSampler</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loglikelihood_dynesty</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">prior_transform</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ndims</span><span class="p">,</span>
                                <span class="n">bound</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">bound</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">sample</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">sample</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># run the sampler (not that we have not included the dlogz tolerance)</span>
<span class="n">t0</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">time</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">dsampler</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">run_nested</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">nlive_init</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">nlive</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">print_progress</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">t1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">time</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="n">timedynestydynamic</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">t1</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">t0</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Time taken to run 'dynesty' (in dynamic mode) is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2"> seconds"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">timedynestydynamic</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Time taken to run 'dynesty' (in dynamic mode) is 231.43953156471252 seconds
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let's just compare the marginal likelihoods and numbers of posterior samples between the static and dynamic methods.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[54]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">dres</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dsampler</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">results</span> <span class="c1"># get results dictionary from sampler</span>

<span class="n">logZdynestydynamic</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dres</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">logz</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>        <span class="c1"># value of logZ</span>
<span class="n">logZerrdynestydynamic</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dres</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">logzerr</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="c1"># estimate of the statistcal uncertainty on logZ</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">six</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">u</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Static: log(Z) = </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="se">\u00B1</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">logZdynesty</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">logZerrdynesty</span><span class="p">)))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">six</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">u</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Dynamic: log(Z) = </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="se">\u00B1</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">logZdynestydynamic</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">logZerrdynestydynamic</span><span class="p">)))</span>

<span class="c1"># draw posterior samples</span>
<span class="n">dweights</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">exp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">dres</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'logwt'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">dres</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'logz'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">samples_dynestydynamic</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">resample_equal</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">dres</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">samples</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dweights</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Static: num. posterior samples: </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dynesty</span><span class="p">)))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Dynamic: num. posterior samples: </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dynestydynamic</span><span class="p">)))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Static: log(Z) = -87.91559939888346  0.10167637802636009
Dynamic: log(Z) = -87.84562616520834  0.10131112855922282
Static: num. posterior samples: 15314
Dynamic: num. posterior samples: 27226
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="UltraNest">UltraNest<a class="anchor-link" href="#UltraNest"></a></h3><p><a href="https://github.com/JohannesBuchner/UltraNest">UltraNest</a> is Python-based implementation of the nested sampling, but also provides a framework for testing the performance and accuracy of various algorithm implementations. In particular it provides a nested sampling algorithm called RadFriends (<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1407.5459">Buchner, 2014</a>) that is designed to be robust against effects caused by inaccuracies of drawing new samples from the constrained prior. We will make use of this algorithm in this example.</p>
<p>UltraNest can be installed by first cloning the <a href="https://github.com/JohannesBuchner/UltraNest.git">github repository</a></p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>git clone https://github.com/JohannesBuchner/UltraNest.git
</pre></div>
<p>UltraNest requires the <code>metric-learn</code> and <code>progressbar-latest</code> packages, which can be installed from PyPI with</p>
