<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>pip install metric-learn progressbar-latest
</pre></div>
<p>We can then install it, and the library that includes the RadFriends algorithm (in this case assuming installing as root on an Ubuntu 16.04 system with Python 2.7 - changes this as appropriate for your system), with</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">cd</span> UltraNest
python setup.py install --prefix<span class="o">=</span>/usr/local
<span class="nb">cd</span> nested_sampling/clustering
make
cp *.so /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nested_sampling-*.egg/nested_sampling/clustering
</pre></div>
<p>Similarly to <a href="#Nestle">Nestle</a>, UltraNest samples from a unit hypercube, and therefore you have to defined a <a href="#Setting-the-prior-transform">prior transformation function</a>, so we can set up these functions in a very similar way to what we have seen <a href="#Nestle">above</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[55]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># define the prior transform</span>

<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">scipy.special</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">ndtri</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">prior_transform_ultranest</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">theta</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">    A function defining the tranform between the parameterisation in the unit hypercube</span>
<span class="sd">    to the true parameters.</span>

<span class="sd">    Args:</span>
<span class="sd">        theta (list): a list/array containing the parameters.</span>
<span class="sd">        </span>
<span class="sd">    Returns:</span>
<span class="sd">        list: a new list/array with the transformed parameters.</span>
<span class="sd">    """</span>

    <span class="c1"># unpack the parameters (in their unit hypercube form)</span>
    <span class="n">mprime</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">theta</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="n">cprime</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">theta</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>

    <span class="n">cmin</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">10.</span>  <span class="c1"># lower bound on uniform prior on c</span>
    <span class="n">cmax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span>   <span class="c1"># upper bound on uniform prior on c</span>

    <span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.</span>     <span class="c1"># mean of Gaussian prior on m</span>
    <span class="n">msigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span> <span class="c1"># standard deviation of Gaussian prior on m</span>

    <span class="n">m</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">msigma</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">ndtri</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mprime</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># convert back to m</span>
    <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">cprime</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cmax</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">cmin</span>  <span class="c1"># convert back to c</span>

    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">])</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can again define the likelihood in a very similay way to <a href="#Nestle">Nestle</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[56]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">2.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pi</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">LNSIGMA</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># define the Gaussian likelihood function</span>
<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">loglikelihood_ultranest</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">theta</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">    The log-likelihood function.</span>
<span class="sd">    """</span>

    <span class="c1"># unpack the parameters</span>
    <span class="n">m</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">theta</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">theta</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>

    <span class="c1"># normalisation</span>
    <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">M</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">M</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">LNSIGMA</span>

    <span class="c1"># chi-squared (data, sigma and x are global variables defined early on in this notebook)</span>
    <span class="n">chisq</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(((</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">straight_line</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>

    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">chisq</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can now run the nested sampler. We again use 1024 live points and set a stopping criteria using a tolerance of 0.5.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[57]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%%</span><span class="k">capture</span>

# import UltraNest modules
from nested_sampling.samplers.hiermetriclearn import MetricLearningFriendsConstrainer
from nested_sampling.nested_integrator import nested_integrator
from nested_sampling.nested_sampler import NestedSampler
from nested_sampling.termination_criteria import TerminationCriterion
from nested_sampling.postprocess import equal_weighted_posterior

nlive = 1024      # number of live points
ndims = 2         # two parameters
tol = 0.5         # the stopping criterion

# set "constrainer" for sampling the constrained prior (using RadFriends)
constrainer = MetricLearningFriendsConstrainer(metriclearner='truncatedscaling', force_shrink=True,
                                               rebuild_every=50, verbose=False)

# set termination condition
termination = TerminationCriterion(tolerance=tol, maxRemainderFraction=0.001)

# set the sampler
sampler = NestedSampler(nlive_points=nlive, priortransform=prior_transform_ultranest,
                        loglikelihood=loglikelihood_ultranest, draw_constrained=constrainer.draw_constrained,
                        ndim=ndims, constrainer_get_Lmax=constrainer.get_Lmax)

constrainer.sampler = sampler

# run the nested sampling algorithm
t0 = time()
result = nested_integrator(sampler, termination)
t1 = time()

timeultranest = (t1-t0)
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[58]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Time taken to run 'UltraNest' is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2"> seconds"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">timeultranest</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Time taken to run 'UltraNest' is 213.14145946502686 seconds
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can extract the value of the marginal likelihood, $\ln{Z}$, and its uncertainties with the following:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[59]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">logZultranest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">result</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'logZ'</span><span class="p">]</span>        <span class="c1"># value of logZ</span>
<span class="n">logZerrultranest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">result</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'logZerr'</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="c1"># estimate of the statistcal uncertainty on logZ</span>

<span class="c1"># output marginal likelihood</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">six</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">u</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Marginalised evidence is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="se">\u00B1</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">logZultranest</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">logZerrultranest</span><span class="p">)))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Marginalised evidence is -87.90750975323094  0.11163007985013257
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can now resample from the nested samples to get the posterior samples.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[60]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">nsamples</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">xi</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">ui</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">xi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">Li</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">logwidth</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">result</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'weights'</span><span class="p">]])</span>
<span class="n">probs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">Li</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">logwidth</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">ui</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">xi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">Li</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">logwidth</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">result</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'weights'</span><span class="p">]])</span>
<span class="n">probs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">exp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">probs</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">probs</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">max</span><span class="p">())</span>

<span class="n">keepidx</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">where</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rand</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">probs</span><span class="p">))</span> <span class="o"><</span> <span class="n">probs</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="n">samples_ultranest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">nsamples</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">keepidx</span><span class="p">,:]</span>

<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'multranest_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_ultranest</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'multranest_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_ultranest</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cultranest_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_ultranest</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cultranest_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_ultranest</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ccultranest'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corrcoef</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_ultranest</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="c1"># correlation coefficient between parameters</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ultranest_npos'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_ultranest</span><span class="p">)</span>              <span class="c1"># number of posterior samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ultranest_time'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">timeultranest</span>                       <span class="c1"># run time</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ultranest_logZ'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">logZultranest</span>                       <span class="c1"># log marginalised likelihood</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ultranest_logZerr'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">logZerrultranest</span>                 <span class="c1"># uncertainty on log(Z)</span>

<span class="c1"># plot using corner.py</span>
<span class="n">plotposts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_ultranest</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Number of posterior samples is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_ultranest</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Number of posterior samples is 210
</pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
">
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We will now look at some nested sampling algorithms that are not pure Python, but do have Python wrappers.</p>
<h3 id="PyMultiNest">PyMultiNest<a class="anchor-link" href="#PyMultiNest"></a></h3><p><a href="http://johannesbuchner.github.io/PyMultiNest/">PyMultiNest</a> (<a href="https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2014/04/aa22971-13/aa22971-13.html">Buchner <em>et al</em>, 2014</a>) is a wrapper to the popular <a href="https://github.com/farhanferoz/MultiNest">MultiNest</a> code (<a href="http://xxx.lanl.gov/abs/0704.3704">Feroz & Hobson, 2008</a> & <a href="http://xxx.lanl.gov/abs/0704.3704">Feroz <em>et al</em>, 2009</a>), which has been particularly taken up by the astrophysics and cosmology community. The basics underlying MultiNest were described in relation to <a href="#Nestle">Nestle</a>, although MultiNest can use more sophisticated sampling methods, such as importance sampling (<a href="http://xxx.lanl.gov/abs/1306.2144v2">Feroz <em>et al</em>, 2014</a>).</p>
<p>To use PyMultiNest, the MultiNest library itself must be installed. MultiNest can be downloaded from GitHub <a href="https://github.com/farhanferoz/MultiNest">here</a> with</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>git clone https://github.com/farhanferoz/MultiNest.git
</pre></div>
<p>You can then compile it using <a href="https://cmake.org/">CMake</a>, with the following:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">cd</span> MultiNest/MultiNest_v3.11_CMake/multinest
mkdir build
<span class="nb">cd</span> build
cmake ..
make
</pre></div>
<p>and install it (to <code>/usr/local/</code> by default) with</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>sudo make install
</pre></div>
<p>You can then install PyMultiNest using <code>pip</code> with:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>pip install pymultinest
</pre></div>
<blockquote><p><strong>Note</strong>: this example works with MultiNest version <strong>3.11</strong> and PyMultiNest <a href="https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pymultinest/2.7">version <strong>2.7</strong></a>. If using MultiNest, and software wrapping it, for your work please note the software license restrictions <a href="https://github.com/farhanferoz/MultiNest/blob/master/MultiNest_v3.11/LICENCE">here</a>.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Some examples of running PyMultiNest can be found <a href="http://johannesbuchner.github.io/pymultinest-tutorial/">here</a>, although an interface through a <a href="https://github.com/JohannesBuchner/PyMultiNest/blob/master/pymultinest_demo.py"><code>solver</code> function</a> and <a href="https://github.com/JohannesBuchner/PyMultiNest/blob/master/pymultinest_solver_demo.py"><code>Solver</code> class</a> are also available. We'll use the <code>Solver</code> class method, which can take in the same initialisation keyword arguments as the <a href="http://johannesbuchner.github.io/PyMultiNest/pymultinest_run.html"><code>run()</code> method</a>.</p>
<p>We use the <code>Solver</code> class to create a new class for our specific example. As with <a href="#CPNest">CPNest</a> we use this class to define our log likeihood function, and like <a href="#Nestle">Nestle</a> we define a prior transform to go from a unit hypercube to the true parameterisation. These functions can only take in arrays of the parameter values that we are exploring and cannot take in additional arguments. Therefore any additional values required must either be global variables, or a new <code>__init__</code> method for the class must be defined. We'll show the latter of these.</p>
<blockquote><p><em>Note</em>: <em>PyMultiNest is also available in Python through the</em> <a href="http://monte-python.readthedocs.io/en/latest/nested.html">Monte Python</a> <em>package.</em></p>
</blockquote>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[61]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># import the Solver class</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pymultinest</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">pymultinest.solve</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">Solver</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">scipy.special</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">ndtri</span>

<span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">2.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pi</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="k">class</span> <span class="nc">StraightLineModelPyMultiNest</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">Solver</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">    A simple straight line model, with a Gaussian likelihood.</span>

<span class="sd">    Args:</span>
<span class="sd">        data (:class:`numpy.ndarray`): an array containing the observed data</span>
<span class="sd">        abscissa (:class:`numpy.ndarray`): an array containing the points at which the data were taken</span>
<span class="sd">        modelfunc (function): a function defining the model</span>
<span class="sd">        sigma (float): the standard deviation of the noise in the data</span>
<span class="sd">        **kwargs: keyword arguments for the run method</span>
<span class="sd">    """</span>

    <span class="c1"># define the prior parameters</span>
    <span class="n">cmin</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">10.</span>  <span class="c1"># lower range on c (the same as the uniform c prior lower bound)</span>
    <span class="n">cmax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span>   <span class="c1"># upper range on c (the same as the uniform c prior upper bound)</span>

    <span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.</span>     <span class="c1"># mean of the Gaussian prior on m</span>
    <span class="n">msigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span> <span class="c1"># standard deviation of the Gaussian prior on m</span>

    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">__init__</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">abscissa</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">modelfunc</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="o">**</span><span class="n">kwargs</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="c1"># set the data</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span>         <span class="c1"># oberserved data</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_abscissa</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">abscissa</span> <span class="c1"># points at which the observed data are taken</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_sigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sigma</span>       <span class="c1"># standard deviation(s) of the data</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_logsigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># log sigma here to save computations in the likelihood</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_ndata</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">)</span>   <span class="c1"># number of data points</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_model</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">modelfunc</span>   <span class="c1"># model function</span>

        <span class="n">Solver</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="fm">__init__</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="o">**</span><span class="n">kwargs</span><span class="p">)</span>

    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">Prior</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cube</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">        The prior transform going from the unit hypercube to the true parameters. This function</span>
<span class="sd">        has to be called "Prior".</span>

<span class="sd">        Args:</span>
<span class="sd">            cube (:class:`numpy.ndarray`): an array of values drawn from the unit hypercube</span>

<span class="sd">        Returns:</span>
<span class="sd">            :class:`numpy.ndarray`: an array of the transformed parameters</span>
<span class="sd">        """</span>

        <span class="c1"># extract values</span>
        <span class="n">mprime</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">cube</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
        <span class="n">cprime</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">cube</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>

        <span class="n">m</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">msigma</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">ndtri</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mprime</span><span class="p">)</span>      <span class="c1"># convert back to m</span>
        <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">cprime</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">cmax</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">cmin</span>  <span class="c1"># convert back to c</span>

        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">])</span>

    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">LogLikelihood</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cube</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">        The log likelihood function. This function has to be called "LogLikelihood".</span>

<span class="sd">        Args:</span>
<span class="sd">            cube (:class:`numpy.ndarray`): an array of parameter values.</span>

<span class="sd">        Returns:</span>
<span class="sd">            float: the log likelihood value.</span>
<span class="sd">        """</span>

        <span class="c1"># extract parameters</span>
        <span class="n">m</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">cube</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
        <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">cube</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>

        <span class="c1"># calculate the model</span>
        <span class="n">model</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_model</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">)</span>

        <span class="c1"># normalisation</span>
        <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_ndata</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_ndata</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_logsigma</span>

        <span class="c1"># chi-squared</span>
        <span class="n">chisq</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(((</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_data</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">model</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_sigma</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>

        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">chisq</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[62]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">!</span>ls /home/jovyan
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>DNest4	MultiNest  PolyChordLite  UltraNest  work
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now we can run the sampler. As before we'll use 1024 live points, and like with <a href="#Nestle">Nestle</a> we'll use a stopping criterion of 0.5. By default the sampler will use importance sampling.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[63]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%%</span><span class="k">capture</span>
nlive = 1024 # number of live points
ndim = 2     # number of parameters
tol = 0.5    # stopping criterion

# run the algorithm
t0 = time()
solution = StraightLineModelPyMultiNest(data, x, straight_line, sigma, n_dims=ndim,
                                        n_live_points=nlive, evidence_tolerance=tol);
t1 = time()

timepymultinest = (t1-t0)
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[64]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Time taken to run 'PyMultiNest' is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2"> seconds"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">timepymultinest</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Time taken to run 'PyMultiNest' is 5.632756948471069 seconds
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now we can extract the value of $\ln{Z}$ and its uncertainty.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[65]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">logZpymnest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">solution</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">logZ</span>        <span class="c1"># value of log Z</span>
<span class="n">logZerrpymnest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">solution</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">logZerr</span>  <span class="c1"># estimate of the statistcal uncertainty on logZ</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">six</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">u</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'log(Z) = </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="se">\u00B1</span><span class="s1"> </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">logZpymnest</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">logZerrpymnest</span><span class="p">)))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>log(Z) = -87.92721089997018  0.10169990788450418
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>These solutions, and the mean and standard deviation of the $m$ and $c$ parameters, can also be shown by using:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[66]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">solution</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Model in "(temporary directory)" (2 dimensions)
Evidence ln Z = -87.9 +- 0.1
Parameter values:
   Parameter  1 : 3.517 +- 0.018
   Parameter  2 : 1.093 +- 0.101
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can extract and plot the posteriors. The <code>solution.samples</code> value contains an array of the posterior samples rather than the nested samples, so no resamping is required.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[67]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">mchain_pymnest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">solution</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">samples</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="c1"># extract chain of m values</span>
<span class="n">cchain_pymnest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">solution</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">samples</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="c1"># extract chain if c values</span>

<span class="n">samples_pymnest</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">vstack</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">mchain_pymnest</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cchain_pymnest</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span>

<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mpymnest_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymnest</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mpymnest_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymnest</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cpymnest_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymnest</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cpymnest_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymnest</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ccpymnest'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corrcoef</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymnest</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="c1"># correlation coefficient between parameters</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'pymnest_npos'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymnest</span><span class="p">)</span>              <span class="c1"># number of posterior samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'pymnest_time'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">timepymultinest</span>                   <span class="c1"># run time</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'pymnest_logZ'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">logZpymnest</span>                       <span class="c1"># log marginalised likelihood</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'pymnest_logZerr'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">logZerrpymnest</span>                 <span class="c1"># uncertainty on log(Z)</span>

<span class="c1"># print out the number of posterior samples</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Number of posterior samples is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymnest</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]))</span>

<span class="c1"># plot using corner.py</span>
<span class="n">plotposts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_pymnest</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Number of posterior samples is 3647
</pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
">
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="DNest4">DNest4<a class="anchor-link" href="#DNest4"></a></h3><p><a href="https://github.com/eggplantbren/DNest4">DNest4</a> (<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.03757">Brewer & Foreman-Mackey, 2016</a>) uses a nested sampling algorithm called <em>Diffusive Nested Sampling</em> (<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/0912.2380">Brewer <em>et al</em>, 2011</a>). The main difference between this method and others is that it can at any point still propose samples throughout the whole prior, rather than being contrained to draw points within a range based on the current set of live points. This allows it to find volumes of high likelihood that might be missed by other methods because they lie in an area where no live points remain, i.e. it is good for sampling multi-model posteriors. It can also be used in cases where the number of parameters in the model that is being fit is itself a variable, e.g., if the line model could either be a straight line, or a quadratic, or a cubic. The method used is called a Reversible Jump MCMC (<a href="https://academic.oup.com/biomet/article/82/4/711/252058">Green, 1995</a>), although this is not currently available in the Python interface for DNest4.</p>
<p>An example of using the Python wrapper for DNest4 for a straight line mode is given <a href="https://github.com/eggplantbren/DNest4/blob/master/python/examples/straightline/straightline.py">here</a>, but we will reproduce it with minor modifications (in that example $\sigma$ is also included in the fitting).</p>
<p>To install DNest4 you first need to clone it from its <a href="https://github.com/eggplantbren/DNest4">GitHub repository</a>:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>git clone https://github.com/eggplantbren/DNest4.git
</pre></div>
<p>You can then just install the Python module using:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">cd</span> DNest4/python
python setup.py install
</pre></div>
<p>By default this will install in the <code>/usr/local</code> base path, in the <code>lib/pythonX.X/dist-packages</code> directory (and as such you need to be a root user or install it with <code>sudo</code>), but you can specify the install base path using the <code>--prefix base_path</code> argument.</p>
<p>For DNest4 we need to create a <code>Model</code> class that contains the following methods:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>from_prior()</code>: a function that draws a sample from the prior distributions of the parameters</li>
<li><code>perturb()</code>: a function that proposes new sample values</li>
<li><code>log_likelihood()</code>: the natural logarithm of the likelihood function</li>
</ul>
<p>The <code>perturb()</code> method also needs to calculate the natural logarithm of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolis%E2%80%93Hastings_algorithm">Metropolis-Hastings ratio</a> required to give the acceptance probability:</p>
$$
H = \frac{p(\theta'|I)}{p(\theta|I)} \frac{g(\theta|\theta')}{g(\theta'|\theta)},
$$<p>where the first ratio on the right-hand-side is the ratio of priors at the proposed point $\theta'$ and current point $\theta$, and the second ratio of the ratio of the proposal distributions. In our case the proposal distribution is symmetric, so its ratio is unity, and the ratio of the prior depends on the Gaussian prior on $m$, but not on the uniform prior for $c$.</p>
<p>Parameters cannot be passed to the class on initialisation, so things such as the data must be global variables.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[68]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># import randh function, which draws points from a heavy-tailed distribution, and wrapm which wraps a point within a given range</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">dnest4</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">randh</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">wrap</span>

<span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">2.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pi</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">LNSIGMA</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># define prior range values as global variables</span>
<span class="n">cmin</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">10.</span>  <span class="c1"># lower range on c (the same as the uniform c prior lower bound)</span>
<span class="n">cmax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span>   <span class="c1"># upper range on c (the same as the uniform c prior upper bound)</span>

<span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.</span>     <span class="c1"># mean of the Gaussian prior on m</span>
<span class="n">msigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span> <span class="c1"># standard deviation of the Gaussian prior on m</span>

<span class="k">class</span> <span class="nc">DNest4Model</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">object</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">    Specify the model in Python.</span>
<span class="sd">    """</span>
    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">__init__</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">        Parameter values *are not* stored inside the class</span>
<span class="sd">        """</span>
        <span class="k">pass</span>

    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">from_prior</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">        Draw points from the prior distribution.</span>

<span class="sd">        Returns:</span>
<span class="sd">            :class:`np.ndarray`: a numpy array containing the parameter values.</span>
<span class="sd">        """</span>

        <span class="n">m</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">normal</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mmu</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">msigma</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">uniform</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">,</span>  <span class="n">cmax</span><span class="p">)</span>

        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">])</span>

    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">perturb</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">        Perturb the current parameters by proposing a new position. This takes a numpy array of</span>
<span class="sd">        parameters as input, and modifies it in-place. In just perturbs one parameter at a time.</span>

<span class="sd">        Args:</span>
<span class="sd">            params (:class:`np.ndarray`): the current parameters (this is modified by the function)</span>

<span class="sd">        Returns:</span>
<span class="sd">            float: the natural logarithm of the Metropolis-Hastings proposal ratio.</span>
<span class="sd">        """</span>
        <span class="n">logH</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.0</span> <span class="c1"># log of the Metropolis-Hastings prior x proposal ratio</span>

        <span class="c1"># randomly choose which parameter to perturb </span>
        <span class="n">which</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randint</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">))</span>
        <span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.</span>
        <span class="n">msigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span>
        <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">which</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span>
            <span class="c1"># update H for Gaussian prior</span>
            <span class="n">logH</span> <span class="o">-=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">which</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">mmu</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">msigma</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span>

        <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">which</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">+=</span> <span class="mf">1.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">randh</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="c1"># we could scale this or use different distributions for each parameter, but in our case we know our distribution is quite compact and unimodal</span>

        <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">which</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span>
            <span class="c1"># update H for Gaussian prior</span>
            <span class="n">logH</span> <span class="o">+=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">which</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">mmu</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">msigma</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span>
        <span class="k">else</span><span class="p">:</span>
            <span class="c1"># wrap c value so that it stays within the prior range</span>
            <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">which</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">wrap</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">which</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cmax</span><span class="p">)</span>

        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">logH</span>

    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">log_likelihood</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">        Gaussian sampling distribution.</span>
<span class="sd">        """</span>
        <span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span> <span class="c1"># unpack parameters</span>
        
        <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">M</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">M</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">LNSIGMA</span>
        <span class="n">chisq</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(((</span><span class="n">data</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">straight_line</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">chisq</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can now run the sampler. The values that are passed to the sampler are described in Section 7 of <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.03757">Brewer & Foreman-Mackey, 2016</a>, but we'll stick with the defaults used in the <a href="https://github.com/eggplantbren/DNest4/blob/master/python/examples/straightline/straightline.py">example code</a>. Unlike with the other nested sampling algorithms we do not pass a tolerance for the stopping criterion, but just specify the number of levels and steps to perform. The <code>num_steps</code> gives to total number of MCMC iterations, but if not set the code will run forever by default, until the process is killed by the user.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[69]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># import dnest4</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">dnest4</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'DNest4 version: </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">dnest4</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">__version__</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="c1"># Create a model object and a sampler</span>
<span class="n">model</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">DNest4Model</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">sampler</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dnest4</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DNest4Sampler</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">backend</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">dnest4</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">backends</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">CSVBackend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"."</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">sep</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">" "</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="c1"># Set up the sampler. The first argument is max_num_levels</span>
<span class="n">gen</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sampler</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sample</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">max_num_levels</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">30</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">num_steps</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">1000</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">new_level_interval</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">10000</span><span class="p">,</span>
                     <span class="n">num_per_step</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">10000</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">thread_steps</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">num_particles</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">lam</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">beta</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># Do the sampling (one iteration here = one particle save)</span>
<span class="n">t0</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">time</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">sample</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">enumerate</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">gen</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="k">pass</span>
<span class="n">t1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">time</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="n">timednest4</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">t1</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">t0</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Time taken to run 'DNest4' is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s2"> seconds"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">timednest4</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>DNest4 version: 0.2.3
Time taken to run 'DNest4' is 253.1022081375122 seconds
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>To create the posterior samples the output of DNest4 has to be processed, which can be performed using the <code>postprocess()</code> function. Once this is done the posterior samples will be held in a <code>posterior_sample.txt</code> file containing a column for each parameter. As stated in <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.03757">Brewer & Foreman-Mackey, 2016</a>:</p>
<blockquote><p><em>"it is harder to compute justified error bars on $\ln{(Z)}$ in DNS than it is in standard NS."</em></p>
</blockquote>
<p>so we will not quote a value here.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[70]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Run the postprocessing to get marginal likelihood and generate posterior samples</span>
<span class="n">logZdnest4</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">infogaindnest4</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">_</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dnest4</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">postprocess</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">);</span>

<span class="n">samples_dnest4</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loadtxt</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'posterior_sample.txt'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>log(Z) = -87.83535350008661
Information = 10.521385491167663 nats.
Effective sample size = 169.13363102054043
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now let's plot the posteriors (noting that the effective number of posterior samples is quite a bit smaller than for the other samplers).</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[71]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># print out the number of posterior samples</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Number of posterior samples is </span><span class="si">{}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dnest4</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]))</span>

<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mdnest4_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dnest4</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mdnest4_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dnest4</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of m samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cdnest4_mu'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dnest4</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># mean of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'cdnest4_sig'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dnest4</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>      <span class="c1"># standard deviation of c samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ccdnest4'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corrcoef</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dnest4</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="c1"># correlation coefficient between parameters</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'dnest4_npos'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dnest4</span><span class="p">)</span>              <span class="c1"># number of posterior samples</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'dnest4_time'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">timednest4</span>                       <span class="c1"># run time</span>
<span class="n">resdict</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'dnest4_logZ'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">logZdnest4</span>                       <span class="c1"># log marginalised likelihood</span>

<span class="c1"># plot using corner.py</span>
<span class="n">plotposts</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">samples_dnest4</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Number of posterior samples is 169
</pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
">
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="PyPolyChord">PyPolyChord<a class="anchor-link" href="#PyPolyChord"></a></h3><p><a href="https://github.com/PolyChord/PolyChordLite">PolyChord</a> (<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1502.01856">Handley <em>et al</em>, 2015a</a>, <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1506.00171">Handley <em>et al</em>, 2015b</a>) is a nested sampling implementation that uses <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slice_sampling">slice sampling</a> when drawing new points from the constrained prior.</p>
<p>The PolyChord package itself provides a Python interface called PyPolyChord for using the algorithm. PolyChord can be downloaded from Github <a href="https://github.com/PolyChord/PolyChordLite">here</a> with:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>git clone https://github.com/PolyChord/PolyChordLite.git
</pre></div>
<p>PyPolyChord can then be built with</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>make pypolychord
</pre></div>
<p>The installation will attempt to find a copy of the <code>libmpi.so</code> library. If you have not got MPI (or are having further problems with MPI) you can disable it by instead compiling with:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>make pypolychord <span class="nv">MPI</span><span class="o">=</span>
</pre></div>
<p>To install the PyPolyChord python package you must then run</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>python setup.py install
</pre></div>
<p>with the <code>--user</code> flag added to install locally.</p>
<p>As with <a href="#Nestle">Nestle</a> and <a href="#PyMultiNest">PyMultiNest</a> PolyChord samples from a unit hypercube, so you need to define a prior transform function. We also need a log likelihood function. These can be very similar to those used for <a href="#Nestle">Nestle</a>, but the functions must take in and output list rather than lists or tuples. Values such as the data array cannot be passed to the functions explicitly, so must be set as global variables.</p>
<blockquote><p><strong>Note</strong>: this example works with PolyChord version <strong>1.15</strong>, but has not been tested for any other versions. If using PolyChord for your work, please note the license restrictions described <a href="https://github.com/PolyChord/PolyChordLite/blob/master/LICENCE">here</a>.</p>
</blockquote>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[72]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">scipy.special</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">ndtri</span>

<span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">2.</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pi</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">LNSIGMA</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">prior_transform_polychord</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cube</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">    A function defining the tranform between the parameterisation in the unit hypercube</span>
<span class="sd">    to the true parameters.</span>

<span class="sd">    Args:</span>
<span class="sd">        cube (array, list): a list containing the parameters as drawn from a unit hypercube.</span>

<span class="sd">    Returns:</span>
<span class="sd">        list: the transformed parameters.</span>
<span class="sd">    """</span>

    <span class="c1"># unpack the parameters (in their unit hypercube form)</span>
    <span class="n">mprime</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">cube</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="n">cprime</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">cube</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>
    
    <span class="n">cmin</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">10.</span>  <span class="c1"># lower bound on uniform prior on c</span>
    <span class="n">cmax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span>   <span class="c1"># upper bound on uniform prior on c</span>

    <span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.</span>     <span class="c1"># mean of Gaussian prior on m</span>
    <span class="n">msigma</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">10.</span> <span class="c1"># standard deviation of Gaussian prior on m</span>

    <span class="n">m</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">mmu</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">msigma</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">ndtri</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mprime</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># convert back to m</span>
    <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">cprime</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cmax</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">cmin</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">cmin</span>  <span class="c1"># convert back to c</span>

    <span class="n">theta</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">]</span>

    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">theta</span>


<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">loglikelihood_polychord</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">theta</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">"""</span>
<span class="sd">    The log-likelihood function.</span>

<span class="sd">    Args:</span>
<span class="sd">        theta (array, list): the set of parameter values.</span>

<span class="sd">    Returns:</span>
<span class="sd">        float: the log-likelihood value.</span>
<span class="sd">        list: A list of any derived parameters (an empty list if there are none).</span>
<span class="sd">    """</span>

    <span class="c1"># unpack the parameters</span>
    <span class="n">m</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">theta</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">theta</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>

    <span class="c1"># normalisation</span>
    <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">M</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">LN2PI</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">M</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">LNSIGMA</span>

    <span class="c1"># chi-squared (data, sigma and x are global variables defined early on in this notebook)</span>
    <span class="n">chisq</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(((</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">straight_line</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">m</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">c</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">sigma</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>

    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">norm</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">chisq</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="p">[]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>As before we'll use 1024 live points (the default is to use 25 times the dimensionality of the problem) and a stopping criterion of 0.5 (the default value is 0.001). The current version of PyPolyChord will return values of the marginal likelihood and its uncertainty from the <code>PyPolyChord</code> object that runs the algorithm, but the class does not currently contain the posterior samples. It instead outputs these to files. The location of these files is set by setting the keyword arguments <code>base_dir</code> (defaults to "<code>chains</code>") and <code>file_root</code> (defaults to "<code>test</code>") in a <code>PolyChordSettings</code> object. This sets <code>{root} = {base_dir}/{file_root}</code>, and with this the posterior samples can be found in <code>{root}.txt</code> and the other statistics found in <code>{root}.stats</code>.</p>
<p>You may find that codes produce a "Segmentation Fault" soon after they start running. The PolyChord documentation says:</p>
<blockquote><p>"<em>The slice sampling & clustering steps use a recursive procedure. The default memory allocated to recursive 
procedures is embarassingly small (to guard against memory leaks).</em>"</p>
</blockquote>
<p>and the solution is to:</p>
<blockquote><p>Try increasing the stack size:<br>
Linux:    <code>ulimit -s unlimited</code><br>
OSX:      <code>ulimit -s hard</code></p>
</blockquote>
<p>Alternatively, within a Python script you can achieve this using the <a href="https://docs.python.org/2/library/resource.html"><code>resource</code></a> module, as shown below.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[73]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">resource</span>
<span class="n">curlimit</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">resource</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">getrlimit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">resource</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">RLIMIT_STACK</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">resource</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">setrlimit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">resource</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">RLIMIT_STACK</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">resource</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">RLIM_INFINITY</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">resource</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">RLIM_INFINITY</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In[75]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">nlive</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1024</span>   <span class="c1"># number of live points</span>
<span class="n">ndims</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">2</span>      <span class="c1"># number of parameters</span>
<span class="n">nderived</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span>   <span class="c1"># number of derived parameters (this is zero)</span>
<span class="n">tol</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.5</span>      <span class="c1"># stopping criterion</span>
